trans-unit.source: Spark on Ubuntu Resource Manager Template
trans-unit.target: Spark on Ubuntu Resource Manager Template

trans-unit.source: Learn to easily deploy a new Spark cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template
trans-unit.target: Learn to easily deploy a new Spark cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template

trans-unit.source: Apache Spark is a fast engine for large-scale data processing.
trans-unit.target: Apache Spark is a fast engine for large-scale data processing.

trans-unit.source: Spark has an advanced DAG execution engine that supports cyclic data flow and in-memory computing, and it can access diverse data sources, including HDFS, Spark, HBase, and S3.
trans-unit.target: Spark has an advanced DAG execution engine that supports cyclic data flow and in-memory computing, and it can access diverse data sources, including HDFS, Spark, HBase, and S3.

trans-unit.source: In addition to running on the Mesos or YARN cluster managers, Spark provides a simple standalone deployment mode.
trans-unit.target: In addition to running on the Mesos or YARN cluster managers, Spark provides a simple standalone deployment mode.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial will walk you through how to use a sample Azure Resource Manager template to deploy a Spark cluster on Ubuntu VMs through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial will walk you through how to use a sample Azure Resource Manager template to deploy a Spark cluster on Ubuntu VMs through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This template deploys a Spark cluster on the Ubuntu virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This template deploys a Spark cluster on the Ubuntu virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: This template also provisions a storage account, virtual network, availability sets, public IP addresses and network interfaces required by the installation.
trans-unit.target: This template also provisions a storage account, virtual network, availability sets, public IP addresses and network interfaces required by the installation.

trans-unit.source: The Spark cluster is created behind a subnet, so there is no public IP access to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: The Spark cluster is created behind a subnet, so there is no public IP access to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: As part of the deployment, an optional "jump box" can be deployed.
trans-unit.target: As part of the deployment, an optional "jump box" can be deployed.

trans-unit.source: This "jump box" is an Ubuntu VM deployed in the subnet as well, but it does expose a public IP address with an open SSH port that you can connect to.
trans-unit.target: This "jump box" is an Ubuntu VM deployed in the subnet as well, but it does expose a public IP address with an open SSH port that you can connect to.

trans-unit.source: Then from the "jump box", you can SSH to all the Spark VMs in the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Then from the "jump box", you can SSH to all the Spark VMs in the subnet.

trans-unit.source: The template utilizes a "t-shirt size" concept in order to specify a "Small", "Medium", or "Large" Spark cluster setup.
trans-unit.target: The template utilizes a "t-shirt size" concept in order to specify a "Small", "Medium", or "Large" Spark cluster setup.

trans-unit.source: When the template language supports more dynamic template sizing, this could be changed to specify the number of Spark cluster master nodes and slave nodes, VM size, etc. For now, you can see the VM size and the number of masters and slaves defined in the file azuredeploy.json in the variables tshirtSizeS, tshirtSizeM, and tshirtSizeL:
trans-unit.target: When the template language supports more dynamic template sizing, this could be changed to specify the number of Spark cluster master nodes and slave nodes, VM size, etc. For now, you can see the VM size and the number of masters and slaves defined in the file azuredeploy.json in the variables tshirtSizeS, tshirtSizeM, and tshirtSizeL:

trans-unit.source: S: 1 master, 1 slave
trans-unit.target: S: 1 master, 1 slave

trans-unit.source: M: 1 master, 4 slaves
trans-unit.target: M: 1 master, 4 slaves

trans-unit.source: L: 1 master, 6 slaves
trans-unit.target: L: 1 master, 6 slaves

trans-unit.source: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article:
trans-unit.target: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: As shown in the above image, the deployment topology consists of the following elements:
trans-unit.target: As shown in the above image, the deployment topology consists of the following elements:

trans-unit.source: A new storage account hosting the OS disk of newly created virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: A new storage account hosting the OS disk of newly created virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: A virtual network with a subnet.
trans-unit.target: A virtual network with a subnet.

trans-unit.source: All the virtual machines created by the template are provisioned inside this virtual network.
trans-unit.target: All the virtual machines created by the template are provisioned inside this virtual network.

trans-unit.source: An availability set for master and slave nodes.
trans-unit.target: An availability set for master and slave nodes.

trans-unit.source: A master node in the newly created availability set.
trans-unit.target: A master node in the newly created availability set.

trans-unit.source: Four slave nodes running in the same virtual subnet and availability set as the master node.
trans-unit.target: Four slave nodes running in the same virtual subnet and availability set as the master node.

trans-unit.source: A jump-box VM located in the same virtual network and subnet that can be used to access the cluster.
trans-unit.target: A jump-box VM located in the same virtual network and subnet that can be used to access the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Spark version 3.0.0 is the default version and can be changed to any pre-built binaries available on the Spark repository.
trans-unit.target: Spark version 3.0.0 is the default version and can be changed to any pre-built binaries available on the Spark repository.

trans-unit.source: There is also a provision in the script to uncomment the build from source.
trans-unit.target: There is also a provision in the script to uncomment the build from source.

trans-unit.source: A static IP address will be assigned to each Spark master node: 10.0.0.10.
trans-unit.target: A static IP address will be assigned to each Spark master node: 10.0.0.10.

trans-unit.source: A static IP address will be assigned to each Spark slave node in order to work around the current limitation of not being able to dynamically compose a list of IP addresses from within the template.
trans-unit.target: A static IP address will be assigned to each Spark slave node in order to work around the current limitation of not being able to dynamically compose a list of IP addresses from within the template.

trans-unit.source: (By default, the first node will be assigned the private IP address of 10.0.0.30, the second node will be assigned 10.0.0.31, and so on.)
trans-unit.target: (By default, the first node will be assigned the private IP address of 10.0.0.30, the second node will be assigned 10.0.0.31, and so on.)

trans-unit.source: To check deployment errors, go to the new Azure portal and look under Resource Group > Last deployment > Check Operation Details.
trans-unit.target: To check deployment errors, go to the new Azure portal and look under Resource Group > Last deployment > Check Operation Details.

trans-unit.source: Before diving into more details related to Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.
trans-unit.target: Before diving into more details related to Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create a Spark cluster by using a Resource Manager template from the GitHub template repository, via either Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create a Spark cluster by using a Resource Manager template from the GitHub template repository, via either Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\Spark).
trans-unit.target: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\Spark).

trans-unit.source: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run these commands:

trans-unit.source: Clone the entire template repository by using a Git client of your choice, for example:
trans-unit.target: Clone the entire template repository by using a Git client of your choice, for example:

trans-unit.source: When the cloning is completed, look for the spark-on-ubuntu folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.
trans-unit.target: When the cloning is completed, look for the spark-on-ubuntu folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.

trans-unit.source: When you create a Spark cluster by using a template, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.
trans-unit.target: When you create a Spark cluster by using a template, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.

trans-unit.source: By declaring these parameters in template definition, it's possible to specify values during deployment execution through an external file or at a command line.
trans-unit.target: By declaring these parameters in template definition, it's possible to specify values during deployment execution through an external file or at a command line.

trans-unit.source: In the "parameters" section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you'll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the "parameters" section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you'll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of the "parameters" section from this template's azuredeploy.json file:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of the "parameters" section from this template's azuredeploy.json file:

trans-unit.source: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.
trans-unit.target: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.

trans-unit.source: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (e.g., Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.
trans-unit.target: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (e.g., Azure PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing runtime values for all parameters.

trans-unit.source: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.
trans-unit.target: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.

trans-unit.source: If you do not include a parameters file, Azure PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.
trans-unit.target: If you do not include a parameters file, Azure PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will need to provide valid values for the parameters storageAccountName, adminUsername, and adminPassword, plus any customizations to the other parameters:
trans-unit.target: Note that you will need to provide valid values for the parameters storageAccountName, adminUsername, and adminPassword, plus any customizations to the other parameters:

trans-unit.source: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.
trans-unit.target: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.

trans-unit.source: Then run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Then run these commands:

trans-unit.source: $RGName must be unique within your subscription.
trans-unit.target: $RGName must be unique within your subscription.

trans-unit.source: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.
trans-unit.target: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (test, production, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (test, production, etc.)

trans-unit.source: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.
trans-unit.target: will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.

trans-unit.source: When deploying, please keep in mind that a new Azure Storage account needs to be created, so the name you provide as the Storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).
trans-unit.target: When deploying, please keep in mind that a new Azure Storage account needs to be created, so the name you provide as the Storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage account (lowercase letters and numbers only).

trans-unit.source: During the deployment, you will see something like this:
trans-unit.target: During the deployment, you will see something like this:

trans-unit.source: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.
trans-unit.target: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.

trans-unit.source: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:
trans-unit.target: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click Browse on the left-hand navigation bar, and then scroll down and click Resource Groups.
trans-unit.target: Click Browse on the left-hand navigation bar, and then scroll down and click Resource Groups.

trans-unit.source: Click the resource group that you just created, to bring up the "Resource Group" blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the resource group that you just created, to bring up the "Resource Group" blade.

trans-unit.source: By clicking the Events bar graph in the Monitoring part of the "Resource Group" blade, you can see the events for your deployment.
trans-unit.target: By clicking the Events bar graph in the Monitoring part of the "Resource Group" blade, you can see the events for your deployment.

trans-unit.source: By clicking individual events, you can drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.
trans-unit.target: By clicking individual events, you can drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>portal-events</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>portal-events</linkText>

trans-unit.target: After your tests, if you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network), use this single command:

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Spark cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location:
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Spark cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a resource group by specifying a name and a location:

trans-unit.source: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above Azure PowerShell section for details) into the following command:
trans-unit.target: Pass this resource group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above Azure PowerShell section for details) into the following command:

trans-unit.source: In order to design a robust and reusable Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like Spark.
trans-unit.target: In order to design a robust and reusable Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like Spark.

trans-unit.source: Leveraging Resource Manager template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it's possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.
trans-unit.target: Leveraging Resource Manager template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it's possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.

trans-unit.source: This diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: This diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>spark-files</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>spark-files</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the Spark cluster.
trans-unit.target: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the Spark cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you have not already downloaded a copy of the template file, designate a local folder as the location for the file and create it (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\Spark).
trans-unit.target: If you have not already downloaded a copy of the template file, designate a local folder as the location for the file and create it (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\Spark).

trans-unit.source: Fill in the folder name and run these commands:
trans-unit.target: Fill in the folder name and run these commands:

trans-unit.source: Open the azuredeploy.json template in a text editor or tool of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Open the azuredeploy.json template in a text editor or tool of your choice.

trans-unit.source: The following information describes the structure of the template file and the purpose of each section.
trans-unit.target: The following information describes the structure of the template file and the purpose of each section.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, you can see the contents of this template in your browser from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, you can see the contents of this template in your browser from <linkText>here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.
trans-unit.target: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.

trans-unit.source: The aforementioned azuredeploy-parameters.json file is used to pass values into the "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.
trans-unit.target: The aforementioned azuredeploy-parameters.json file is used to pass values into the "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of a parameter for the "t-shirt size":
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of a parameter for the "t-shirt size":

trans-unit.source: Notice that defaultValue may be specified, as well as allowedValues.
trans-unit.target: Notice that defaultValue may be specified, as well as allowedValues.

trans-unit.source: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.
trans-unit.target: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.

trans-unit.source: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.
trans-unit.target: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples that range from simple to more complex:
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples that range from simple to more complex:

trans-unit.source: The vmStorageAccountContainerName variable is an example of a simple name/value variable.
trans-unit.target: The vmStorageAccountContainerName variable is an example of a simple name/value variable.

trans-unit.source: vnetID is an example of a variable that is calculated at run time using the functions resourceId and parameters.
trans-unit.target: vnetID is an example of a variable that is calculated at run time using the functions resourceId and parameters.

trans-unit.source: The value of the numberOfMasterInstances and vmSize variables are calculated at run time using the concat, variables, and parameters functions.
trans-unit.target: The value of the numberOfMasterInstances and vmSize variables are calculated at run time using the concat, variables, and parameters functions.

trans-unit.source: If you want to customize the size of the Spark cluster deployment, then you can change the properties of the variables tshirtSizeS, tshirtSizeM, and tshirtSizeL in the azuredeploy.json template.
trans-unit.target: If you want to customize the size of the Spark cluster deployment, then you can change the properties of the variables tshirtSizeS, tshirtSizeM, and tshirtSizeL in the azuredeploy.json template.

trans-unit.source: More information regarding the template language can be found on MSDN at <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More information regarding the template language can be found on MSDN at <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The "resources" section is where most of the action happens.
trans-unit.target: The "resources" section is where most of the action happens.

trans-unit.source: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases.
trans-unit.target: Looking carefully inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases.

trans-unit.source: The first is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that essentially invokes a nested deployment within the main one.
trans-unit.target: The first is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that essentially invokes a nested deployment within the main one.

trans-unit.source: The second is the templateLink property (and related contentVersion property) that makes it possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked, passing a set of parameters as input.
trans-unit.target: The second is the templateLink property (and related contentVersion property) that makes it possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked, passing a set of parameters as input.

trans-unit.source: These can be seen in this template fragment:
trans-unit.target: These can be seen in this template fragment:

trans-unit.source: From this first example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files.
trans-unit.target: From this first example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files.

trans-unit.source: Each file is responsible for part of the required deployment activities.
trans-unit.target: Each file is responsible for part of the required deployment activities.

trans-unit.source: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: shared-resource.json: contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.
trans-unit.target: shared-resource.json: contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Examples are Storage accounts used to store a VM's OS disks and virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Examples are Storage accounts used to store a VM's OS disks and virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: jumpbox-resources-enabled.json: deploys the "jump box" VM and all related resources, such as network interface, public IP address, and the input endpoint used to SSH into the environment.
trans-unit.target: jumpbox-resources-enabled.json: deploys the "jump box" VM and all related resources, such as network interface, public IP address, and the input endpoint used to SSH into the environment.

trans-unit.source: After invoking these two templates, azuredeploy.json provisions all Spark cluster node VMs and connected resources (network adapters, private IPs, etc.).
trans-unit.target: After invoking these two templates, azuredeploy.json provisions all Spark cluster node VMs and connected resources (network adapters, private IPs, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This template will also deploy VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invoke a bash script (spark-cluster-install.sh) to physically install and set up Spark on each node.
trans-unit.target: This template will also deploy VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invoke a bash script (spark-cluster-install.sh) to physically install and set up Spark on each node.

trans-unit.source: Let's drill down into how this last template, azuredeploy.json, is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.
trans-unit.target: Let's drill down into how this last template, azuredeploy.json, is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.

trans-unit.source: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance, it can set unique values for required settings.
trans-unit.target: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance, it can set unique values for required settings.

trans-unit.source: This concept is known as resource looping.
trans-unit.target: This concept is known as resource looping.

trans-unit.source: A resource that uses the copy element will "copy" itself for the number of times specified in the count parameter of the copy element.
trans-unit.target: A resource that uses the copy element will "copy" itself for the number of times specified in the count parameter of the copy element.

trans-unit.source: For all settings where it is necessary to specify unique values between different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.
trans-unit.target: For all settings where it is necessary to specify unique values between different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.

trans-unit.source: In the following fragment from azuredeploy.json, you can see this concept applied to multiple network adapters, VMs, and VM extensions being created for the Spark cluster:
trans-unit.target: In the following fragment from azuredeploy.json, you can see this concept applied to multiple network adapters, VMs, and VM extensions being created for the Spark cluster:

trans-unit.source: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.
trans-unit.target: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.

trans-unit.source: In this particular template, you can see that the Spark cluster nodes are dependent on the shared resources and networkInterfaces resources being created first.
trans-unit.target: In this particular template, you can see that the Spark cluster nodes are dependent on the shared resources and networkInterfaces resources being created first.

trans-unit.source: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node.
trans-unit.target: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node.

trans-unit.source: In this case, this is used to install and set up Spark on each VM node.
trans-unit.target: In this case, this is used to install and set up Spark on each VM node.

trans-unit.source: Let's look at a snippet from the azuredeploy.json template that uses these:
trans-unit.target: Let's look at a snippet from the azuredeploy.json template that uses these:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the extension for the master and slave node resources executes different commands, defined in the commandToExecute property, as part of the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the extension for the master and slave node resources executes different commands, defined in the commandToExecute property, as part of the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: If you look at the JSON snippet of the latest virtual machine extension, you can see that this resource depends on the virtual manchine resource and its network interface.
trans-unit.target: If you look at the JSON snippet of the latest virtual machine extension, you can see that this resource depends on the virtual manchine resource and its network interface.

trans-unit.source: This indicates that these two resources need to be already deployed before provisioning and running this VM extension.
trans-unit.target: This indicates that these two resources need to be already deployed before provisioning and running this VM extension.

trans-unit.source: Also note the use of the copyindex() function to repeat this step for each slave virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Also note the use of the copyindex() function to repeat this step for each slave virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.
trans-unit.target: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-node solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.

trans-unit.source: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as highlighted by the following diagram:
trans-unit.target: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as highlighted by the following diagram:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>spark-template-structure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>spark-template-structure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In essence, this approach suggests to:
trans-unit.target: In essence, this approach suggests to:

trans-unit.source: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub-template executions.
trans-unit.target: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub-template executions.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (storage accounts, virtual network configuration, etc.).
trans-unit.target: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (storage accounts, virtual network configuration, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific to a given resource.
trans-unit.target: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific to a given resource.

trans-unit.source: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.
trans-unit.target: For identical members of a group of resources (nodes in a cluster, etc.), create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.

trans-unit.source: For all post-deployment tasks (product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.
trans-unit.target: For all post-deployment tasks (product installation, configurations, etc.), leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Read more details on <linkText>deploying a template</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Read more details on <linkText>deploying a template</linkText><title></title>.
